result.execSummary:
The defendant Lawrence A. Cleveland was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Battery [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 940.19(1).
  • Disorderly Conduct [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse], a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
SAFE Program; assessment/counseling/treatment as deemed appropriate by the agent; written by defendant to victim should be furnished to victim if probation agent deems it appropriate. **COURT finds defendant is entitled to 2 days jail credit if revoked.**

If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  

A copy of the police report has been faxed to the probation office.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

Modified Bond sent to Atty Mansell for client's signature

**Bond Modified to permit drop off and pick up of the parties' child at the residence of the Defendant's mother or the Defendant's father according to the terms of Paragraph 6 of the Order in Marathon County case 14CV282.  The Defendant may communicate with Mrs. Cleveland solely about the child by the exchange of a notebook at the time of the exchange.  The Defendant shall be required to sign a modified bond containing these terms.**  No contact with victim(s): K.C. (non-waivable)
Contact includes direct personal or physical and indirect contact by phone, in writing of any kind, entry to the person's residence or place of employment together with contacts through other persons.  Contact, however, may be made through the defendant's attorney. Police escort to retrieve any personal belongings.  Third party visitation through J.C.
